title-group.article-title: Analysis and simulation of the gearshift methodology for a novel two-speed transmission system for electric powertrains with a central motor

abstract.p: Electric vehicle powertrains traditionally consist of a central electric motor drive, a single-speed transmission and a differential. This electric powertrain layout, for use in either fully electric vehicles or through-the-road parallel hybrid electric vehicles, will be extensively adopted in the next few years, despite the ongoing research in electric vehicles with individually controlled motors. However, current research suggests that electric powertrains with a central electric motor drive can still be widely improved. For example, the installation of a seamless multiple-speed transmission instead of a single-speed transmission can cause an increase in the vehicle performance, together with an enhancement in the overall efficiency of the electric powertrain. These novel transmission systems for electric powertrains require a specific design, in order to be efficient, compact, easy and robust to control and cheap to manufacture. This article presents the mechanical layout and the control system of a novel two-speed transmission system designed by the present authors, with particular focus on the achievement of optimal gearshift dynamics. The torque characteristics of typical electric motor drives require a different actuation of the seamless gearshifts, in comparison with the equivalent operation for a dual-clutch transmission within a powertrain driven by an internal combustion engine.

sec.title: The benefits of multiple-speed transmission systems for electric powertrains
sec.p: Because of the nature of the torque characteristics of typical electric vehicle traction motors, electric vehicles (or electric axles for through-the-road parallel hybrid electric vehicles) are generally equipped with a single-speed transmission. This is because electric motors exhibit a high constant torque from zero to base speed and then enter into a constant-power region for higher angular velocities. Further benefits of a central motor drive equipped with only a single-speed transmission are reductions in the drivetrain mass, volume, losses and cost.1–3

Despite the wide operational speed range of such traction motors (e.g. from 0 to 8000–12,000 r/min), a multiple-speed transmission4–6 may be employed to enhance the vehicle’s performance. In particular, the wheel torque at low velocities of the vehicle is increased together with the maximum road gradient that the vehicle can ascend when transporting heavy payloads. In addition, the lower second-gear ratio raises the vehicle’s top speed.

As an example, Figure 1 shows the wheel torque envelopes achievable through a single-speed transmission in traction and regeneration, and the same characteristics for each gear of a two-speed transmission system. The case study vehicle for Figures 1 and 2 is a prototype electric minibus wherein the electric motor drive is characterised by a limited regenerative capability owing to the design of the power electronics. The two-speed transmission results in an increase of approximately 34% of the peak value of the wheel torque over the single-speed axle, namely 800 Nm. Also, Figure 1 demonstrates the benefit in the vehicle’s top speed. At a road gradient of 0%, the single-speed vehicle (in unladen conditions) is characterised by a top speed VMax,SS,0% of 119 km/h, limited by the maximum speed of the electric motor (8000 r/min for the motor in this case study). The top speed VMax,TS,0% for the two-speed vehicle is 149 km/h, which is limited by the available motor power but still shows a gain of 24% over the single-speed transmission vehicle.

caption.p: Potential performance benefit deriving from the adoption of a two-speed transmission system over a single-speed transmission system for the case study vehicle.
Potential energy efficiency benefit deriving from the adoption of a two-speed transmission system.

sec.p: Moreover, in most cases the overall efficiency of the electric motor drive and energy storage unit varies significantly as a function of the operating torque and speed. The adoption of a two-speed transmission can facilitate significant energy benefits through optimisation of the operating points of the electric powertrain over a given driving schedule. Consequently, selection of the gear ratio is as important as in the case of a conventional vehicle driven by an internal combustion engine. The efficiency of a multiple-speed transmission system is generally lower than the efficiency of the single-speed transmission for the same vehicle, at least in terms of the losses relating to the presence of an actuation system and the increased mass. However, this variation for conventional transmission systems based on a layshaft layout is usually marginal in comparison with the potential increase in the overall powertrain efficiency. Evidence of this has been comprehensively provided by Ren et al.4 and by Sorniotti and co-workers.7 As an example, Figure 2 presents the distribution of the operating points on the efficiency map of the electric motor drive during a New European Driving Cycle (NEDC). The results are compared with those for the vehicle in the same case study as shown in Figure 1; the vehicle is equipped with a single-speed transmission and a two-speed transmission. The two-speed transmission system predominantly operates in second gear at higher electric motor torques and lower speeds than the single-speed transmission does and consequently in a higher-efficiency region of the motor drive. Not only is this conclusion true for this singular case but also diagrams and results similar to those in Figures 1 and 2 have been derived for very different vehicle typologies and electric powertrain characteristics by one of the present authors and co-workers.7

The existing literature suggests that two-speed transmission systems are the most suitable solution for increasing the efficiency and performance of electric axles,7–11 without adding significant complexity and mass. Sorniotti and co-workers9,10 have summarised the optimisation procedures implemented for the choice of gear ratios and gearshift map for two-speed transmission systems for electric axles. In particular, along a set of typical driving schedules the energy consumption is reduced by approximately 10%, in comparison with the single-speed vehicle equipped with the same motor drive and energy storage unit. Di Nicola11 adopted the same optimisation procedure as in the work by Sorniotti and co-workers9,10 in order to demonstrate that a multiple-speed transmission system can permit a significant reduction in the peak torque of the electric motor drive for the same value of its peak power. The downsizing (in the peak torque) of the electric powertrain implies an additional benefit in terms of the mass, energy consumption and manufacturing cost.

This article presents the description of a novel transmission system layout specifically designed for electric powertrains and the mathematical equations for modelling the overall system dynamics. In addition, the principles of the methodology developed for controlling the upshifts and downshifts with the new transmission are derived. The issues which need to be addressed when designing a seamless gearshift control for electric powertrains are discussed in great detail through a comprehensive set of simulation results.

sec.title: The novel transmission system
sec.p: A multiple-speed transmission system must be able to accomplish seamless gearshifts in order to be competitive with a single-speed transmission for electric axles. A seamless gearshift is particularly relevant as a large number of upshifts (in conditions of medium-torque to high-torque demands) are carried out in the constant-power region of the electric motor, which can result in a more perceivable torque gap for a non-seamless gearshift.

Seamless gearshifts can be achieved by using a cascade of planetary gear sets, as presented by Koneda and Stockton12, with a one-way clutch used to provide the torque reaction in first gear during traction. A hydraulic actuation system is adopted for the control of the two friction clutches required for the second gear, the reverse gear and regeneration. An alternative seamless multiple-speed transmission layout for electric vehicle applications can be based on the adoption of a dual-clutch system on a layshaft-type transmission, as described by Webster.13 This solution is becoming common for vehicles driven by an internal combustion engine but is characterised by significant mechanical complexity and requires careful control of the actuation of the ongoing and offgoing friction clutches.14 As a consequence, this layout is suitable for transmission systems characterised by at least three gear ratios, but more cost-effective solutions can be evaluated for seamless two-speed transmissions for electric vehicles. In particular, according to Goetz et al.,15,16 the use of one-way clutches can improve the shift quality to a great extent, as their ability to disengage automatically if the input torque becomes negative benefits the control of a clutch-to-clutch gearshift. An alternative design solution for the implementation of seamless gearshifts is based on a novel design of the synchronising rings and their actuation.17

The novel two-speed transmission system of this paper combines the mechanical simplicity of a layshaft-type transmission, with the high quality of a clutch-to-clutch gearshift. Its primary components are a one-way sprag clutch located on the secondary shaft and a friction clutch on the primary shaft together with an open differential, as displayed in Figure 3. The input torque is transmitted by the sprag clutch while in first gear, and by the friction clutch while in second gear. The system can work either as a fully automated transmission or as an automated manual transmission through a seamless shift system.18 The friction clutch is applied to transfer torque from the sprag clutch during an upshift and is released to allow the sprag clutch to engage to accomplish a downshift. A full description of the gearshift methodology is presented in the fourth section of this paper.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the transmission operation in (a) first gear and (b) second gear.

sec.p: The multi-disc friction clutch utilises sintered metal friction material and is electrohydraulically controlled using a remote brushless motor-driven actuator, pressurising a master cylinder mechanically connected to the Belleville spring of the friction clutch. The friction clutch actuation system is controlled through a feedback loop based on actuator displacement. In order to allow regenerative energy recovery while decelerating in first gear, the engagement of a locking ring, electromechanically actuated, prevents the one-way sprag clutch from overrunning when the direction of torque through the transmission is reversed. Once the vehicle has come to rest, the gearshift mechanism can also be used as a park lock by simultaneously engaging the locking ring and closing the friction clutch, thus eliminating the need for a separate park lock mechanism and actuator. The mechanical layout of the two-speed transmission results in a compact design, with the overall distance between the primary and differential shaft being about 200 mm for a premium passenger car. Furthermore, for this application the distance from the primary shaft to the secondary shaft is less than 110 mm and from the secondary shaft to the differential is approximately 125 mm. The transmission with this layout results in a mass of about 38 kg. The dimensions and weight are comparable with those of the single-speed unit (mass, 25 kg) from which this novel transmission was derived.

sec.title: Transmission dynamics: governing principles
sec.p: The best methodology for developing the control system for the gearshift actuation is through the analysis of the equations governing the overall system dynamics.19 Starting from the basic physical principles described in this section, the control system for the gearshift actuation will be described in detail in the following section.

Derivation of the equations governing the dynamics of the bespoke two-speed transmission system has been carried out by seven of the present authors and a co-worker,20 and therefore only the final dynamic equations are presented here. In the following description of the first-order system dynamics, the plays and internal torsion deformations of the transmission components, and in particular of the engaged sprag clutch, are not considered as they are second-approximation effects in relation to the gearshift control analysis which is the focus of the article. In fact, these characteristics do not affect the acceleration profile of the vehicle in conditions of constant gear or upshift–downshift. Experimental tests on the sprag clutch have revealed that its internal elastic deformation, which is proportional to the transmitted torque (with a maximum torsion angle of 2–3°), is negligible in comparison with the torsion dynamics of the half-shafts, from the viewpoint of the vehicle’s low-frequency drivability.
The transmission system can work in three states, each of which is characterised by different governing equations.

list-item.p: Engaged first gear. In this condition, the kinematic ratio of of the electric motor shaft’s speed to the transmission output shaft’s speed is equal to the first-gear ratio, and the friction clutch can be transmitting torque while slipping during a gearshift (the torque phase of the gearshift).

The inertia phase of the gearshift. In this condition, both clutches are slipping, and the transmission system is characterised by two degrees of freedom, as the electric motor dynamics are decoupled from the transmission output shaft dynamics.
Engaged second gear. In this condition, the friction clutch is engaged and no torque is transmitted through the sprag clutch, which is overrunning.

sec.title: System dynamics in the frequency domain
sec.p: Figure 4 illustrates the overall system dynamics in the three states described in the sections on the engaged first gear, the inertia phase of the gearshift and the engaged second gear, considering the overall torque of the half-shaft as an output with the inputs being the reference torque of the electric motor drive when the gears are engaged, or the torque of the friction clutch during the inertia phase. These Bode diagrams were obtained from a linearised model of the overall system, including the dynamics of the electric motor drive, the actuation system of the friction clutch, the relaxation length and slip of the tyres, and the compliance of the half-shaft.

The variation in the first natural frequency of the driveline is evident from first gear to second gear owing to the lower value of the equivalent moment of inertia (at the wheels) of the electric motor. The high damping of the system in conditions of an engaged gear is due to the significant time constant of the specific electric motor drive. Low values of the motor time constant would make the system response underdamped, with an evident peak in the response at the first natural frequency. The natural frequency is subjected to a further significant increase during the inertia phase, as the equivalent moment of inertia of the drivetrain is reduced when the electric motor is decoupled from the wheels. The amplitude of the frequency response is reduced between 1 Hz and 25 Hz during the inertia phase, owing to the dynamic characteristics (time constant) of the friction clutch actuator.

sec.title: Upshift control
sec.p: The control of the upshifts for such a transmission system is similar to the methodology usually adopted for dual-clutch transmission systems, with some differences to compensate for the characteristics of the electric powertrain. In this section, upshifts during power-on are analysed.

In order to shift to second gear, first the locking ring is disengaged. The torque phase is then initiated by the progressive engagement of the friction clutch at a rate limited by the dynamic properties (the reaction time and the rise time) of the electrohydraulic actuation system. This causes a reduction in the torque Tsc transmitted through the sprag clutch while the system is kinematically in first gear and consequently changes the transmission output torque from the first-gear value to the second-gear value. The progressive transition reduces the drivetrain oscillations which can be observed in a conventional manual transmission system, where the disengagement of the clutch typically causes an interruption of the half-shaft torque and produces consequent excitation of the torsional dynamics of the system. The basic version of the control system presented in this paper, called control 1, does not manipulate the driver torque demand (DTD), which is directly sent to the motor drive, during the torque phase of the upshift.
At the end of the torque phase the torque Tsc of the sprag clutch becomes null for the torque value of the friction clutch identified by the equation

Tfc is estimated by the control system from the displacement of the actuator of the friction clutch. Equation (8) establishes the beginning of the inertia phase of the upshift, during which the electric motor speed has to be reduced from the value for the first-gear ratio to the value for the second-gear ratio, while keeping an adequate acceleration profile for the vehicle. The principles for inertia phase control can be derived from equations (3) and (4). During the inertia phase, the vehicle’s acceleration dynamics are controlled by the torque of the friction clutch (equation (4)), while the difference between the torques of the electric motor and the friction clutch affects the motor dynamics (equation (3)). As a consequence, the two degrees of freedom of the system can be independently controlled, provided that the electric motor drive is not working in conditions of saturation (on its peak torque characteristic, which represents the constraint of the control system). This is the ‘golden rule’ for control of the inertia phase of the gearshifts in such a system.

During the inertia phase of the upshift for control 1, Tfc is ramped up according to an open-loop control system at the same rate as the torque phase to reduce any driveline oscillations during phase transitions. Tfc ramps to a reference level equal to the torque value that the electric motor would produce for the actual condition of DTD(t) (not manipulated by the controller) and the electric motor speed. sec.p: The parameters of the electric motor controller can vary depending on the DTD and speed, in order to make the upshift quicker or more comfortable as a function of the specific driving situation. In any case, the motor controller has a very small impact on the low-frequency drivability of the vehicle during the upshift, as this is controlled through the friction clutch (equation (9)), consistent with the ‘golden rule’. Therefore, the performance of the system is very robust against the variations in the parameters of the feedback motor controller. Tests were successfully carried out when only the feedforward system reduced the torque of the electric motor drive by a constant amount and therefore had no contribution from the PID controller; this resulted in little variation in the perceivable quality of the achieved results.

At the conclusion of the inertia phase, when the friction clutch engages, the actuator of the friction clutch is moved to its end stop where the transmissible torque of the clutch is at the nominal level, depending on the wear condition of the clutch discs.

The upshift control system described until now (control 1) gives rise to a complete absence of torque gap during the upshift when the initial and the final operating points of the electric motor drive are in the constant-torque region of the electric motor. For example, this condition is satisfied for the upshifts from point A to point B or from point C to point D in Figure 7. For upshifts in the constant-power region of the electric motor drive, such as those from point E to point F or from point G to point H, the torque phase of the upshift, when operated as described for control 1, involves a reduction in the wheel torque. For the same conditions, the inertia phase implies a progressive increase in the wheel torque, consistent with a reduction in the electric motor speed and a subsequent increase in Tfc,saturation,IP,US (equation (9)). These variations in the wheel torque, especially the increase during the inertia phase, are progressive and cause lower jerk levels (the time derivative of the vehicle’s acceleration) and significantly better acceleration profiles than those experienced in a conventional single-clutch transmission. This is because the single-clutch transmission suffers from negative values of the vehicle’s acceleration during the phase of the upshift characterised by the disengaged clutch. The control system defined as control 1 is reliable, robust and relatively simple; therefore it is currently adopted on the first transmission prototypes installed in an electric minibus demonstrator and on the hardware-in-the-loop electric axle rig at the University of Surrey.

sec.p: In order to reduce the torque gap significantly during the inertia phase of the upshift, it is possible to adopt for the friction clutch saturation level the control characteristic, here named control 2, given by

The control system provokes the friction clutch to transmit a torque level equal to the value that the electric motor would generate if the system was already in second gear. The adoption of the torque of the friction clutch given by equation (12) during the inertia phase of the upshift significantly improves the vehicle’s acceleration, as it eliminates the partial torque gap of the wheel during the inertia phase of the upshift. However, it generates a significant jerk level in the vehicle in the transition between the torque phase and the inertia phase of the upshift. This is because the torque phase of the upshift, when implemented according to control 1 and control 2, intrinsically produces a reduction in the available wheel torque, which is progressively recovered in the case of control 1 but quite abruptly recovered in the case of control 2. Control 2 could be adopted as a sport-oriented transmission control algorithm selectable by the driver.

In the case of an upshift in the constant-power region of the electric motor, it is possible to compensate for the reduction in the wheel torque, induced by the torque shift from the first to the second gear (the torque phase of the upshift), by manipulating the electric motor torque demand. During this transition, careful tuning of the control parameters has to be carried out, paying particular attention to the dynamics of the friction clutch actuator and the electric motor. The system’s sensitivity to the clutch actuator dynamics has already been demonstrated.20

sec.title: Downshift control
sec.p: As a first approximation, the downshift actuation sequence is a reverse of the upshift method, wherein the inertia phase precedes the torque phase. Downshifts in power-on are actuated following significant increases in the DTD, in order to increase the amount of wheel torque. Because of the significantly lower frequency of downshifts in power-on in comparison with the upshifts (a consequence of the usual gear selection algorithms), the control system adopted in the inertia phase is a simplified version of that presented for the upshifts, even if potentially the control systems could be similar.

Downshifts in power-on are accomplished by initially opening the friction clutch at the rate allowed by the actuator dynamics. When the clutch’s transmissible torque is lower than the electric motor’s torque, the clutch starts to slip, giving rise to the inertia phase. The motor’s torque is kept at the level requested by the user, while the friction clutch’s torque is controlled in order to produce the required acceleration level of the electric motor shaft. At the start of the inertia phase, the friction clutch actuator position should be carefully monitored because the dynamic friction coefficient of the dry friction clutch is lower than the static friction coefficient. The manipulation of the torques of both the motor and the friction clutch (according to the ‘golden rule’ presented in the section on upshift control) during the inertia phase of the downshift in power-on would lead to full controllability of both the dynamics of the electric motor and the acceleration of the vehicle, at the cost of a significantly increased complexity of the control system and the time required to tune its parameters for application to each vehicle. The friction clutch can be momentarily re-engaged when the sprag clutch is about to connect (the beginning of the torque phase of the downshift), in order to dampen the re-engagement of the sprag clutch and to reduce any jerk.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: A non-linear vehicle simulation model was implemented in order to evaluate the gearshift dynamics of the novel transmission system. The equations utilised to model the transmission dynamics were presented in the third section ‘Transmission dynamics: governing principles’.

The developed simulator is characterised by a detailed transmission efficiency model, based on the efficiency maps for the transmission and the final reduction ratio (functions of the torque, the speed and the operating temperature), created by two of the present authors and a co-worker22 through specific models and validated through experimental tests carried out on other transmission systems. These efficiency maps include the efficiency of the actual gear couplings, the losses due to the transmission bearings, the sprag clutch losses and the losses due to oil churning and windage. This permits an overall equivalent efficiency for the subsystem (the gearbox or final reduction ratio) to be calculated which is then re-assigned, within the dynamic simulator, to the gear coupling of the first gear, second gear and final reduction ratio. Figures 8 and 9 plot the equivalent efficiency maps for the transmission, including the final reduction ratio, in the first gear and second gear (characterised by the higher efficiency values) respectively.

caption.p: Efficiency map of the novel transmission system in first gear at 40 °C (including the efficiency relating to the final reduction ratio).
Efficiency map of the novel transmission system in second gear at 40 °C (including the efficiency relating to the final reduction ratio).

sec.p: The simulation model includes the estimation of the temperature dynamics of the electric powertrain components (air-cooled transmission), and in particular the thermal dissipation within the friction clutch during the gearshifts, which are fed into the efficiency model. The model also considers the wear in the system and the play in the actuation of the clutch, which is evident in the delay between the motion of the pressure plate and the actual torque on the friction clutch. The transmission model includes the torsional dynamics of the half-shafts; the tyres are modelled using the ‘magic formula’ given by Pacejka23 with the tyre relaxation length. The adopted vehicle dynamics simulator permits the detailed modelling of the longitudinal dynamics of the vehicle and has already been experimentally validated by one of the present authors and co-workers7 on electric vehicle applications equipped with single-speed transmission systems. The main parameters of the vehicle adopted for the simulation results of Figures 10 to 15 are listed in Table 2 in Appendix 2. The motor drive data were selected to have a high moment of inertia and slow reaction time to test the robustness of the proposed controllers in critical conditions.

sec.title: Upshift
sec.p: Figures 10 and 11 summarise the overall transmission system dynamics for an upshift at a DTD of 80%, carried out when the vehicle’s speed is 75 km/h, in the constant-power region of the electric motor drive and using control system control 3.

The phases of the upshift, namely the upshift request, followed by the torque phase, the inertia phase (defined by the labels Inertia Phase Start and Inertia Phase End) and the final motion of the actuator after the engagement of the second gear (labelled Actuator Stop), are evident in the graphs. The effects of the efficiencies and the moments of inertia of the components are also visible in the graphs, e.g. in the marginal difference between the torque of the electric motor and the input torques transmitted by the first gear and second gear when a gear is engaged in Figure 10.

During the torque phase the electric motor’s torque demand is modified according to equation (13) and is increased in order to compensate for the reduction in the vehicle’s acceleration induced by the torque transfer from first gear to second gear. Because of the sharp gradient in the reference speed of the electric motor at the start of the inertia phase, the feedforward–feedback controller shown in Figure 5 causes a large decrease in the electric motor torque (Figure 10). The torque of the friction clutch is ramped up to make the vehicle’s acceleration equal to the level of the vehicle’s acceleration in second gear, according to equation (12). In the second part of the inertia phase the rate of the motor’s reference speed is reduced, as shown in Figure 5, and consequently the electric motor’s torque demand is increased. Moreover, as the speed of the electric motor decreases, the maximum available torque increases owing to the torque map of the electric motor (Figure 7). This justifies the difference between the first-gear torque and the second-gear torque in the conditions of an engaged gear in Figure 10 and represents the main peculiarity to be taken into account in the implementation of algorithms for gearshift control of electric powertrains.

The torque actually transmitted by the friction clutch and the maximum torque which can be potentially transmitted (transmissible torque) for an assigned clutch actuator displacement are the same when the clutch is slipping while they differ when the clutch is engaged, as in Figure 11. This is evident after the inertia phase, when the transmissible torque of the friction clutch is increased owing to the change between the dynamic and static friction coefficients of the clutch. Finally the actuator is moved to increase the axial force of the friction clutch and therefore the transmissible torque. Notably, Figure 11 shows that the torque of the friction clutch transmitted in second gear is lower than that transmitted by the sprag clutch in first gear because the friction clutch is located on the primary shaft while the sprag clutch is located on the secondary shaft, as illustrated in Figure 3.

In addition, Figure 11 illustrates that the pressure plate moves when the shift is initiated to take up any play between the clutch plates. After recovering the play, during the torque and inertia phases of the upshift there is an infinitesimal axial movement of the pressure plate due to the high axial stiffness of the clutch plates, although the transmissible torque varies with the actuator travel of the friction clutch, which depends on the stiffness properties of the Belleville spring.

Figure 12 plots the time history of the gearbox output shaft torque for the same manoeuvre as in Figures 10 and 11, and during an upshift at a DTD of 40%, carried out at 30 km/h, in the constant-torque region of the electric motor drive. Both manoeuvres were simulated by adopting control 3. The marginal torque gap induced by the torque phase of the upshift and recovered by the friction clutch control during the inertia phase is evident in the first manoeuvre. The second manoeuvre is characterised by the total absence of any torque gap. This characteristic is common to control 1, control 2 and control 3, when the upshift is requested in the constant-torque region of the electric motor unit. The equivalent moment of inertia of the transmission is very high in first gear and very low during the inertia phase and it is this change which provokes some marginal oscillations in the gearbox output shaft torque.

Figure 13 compares the vehicle’s acceleration profiles achievable during two different upshifts at a DTD of 40% (different manoeuvre from Figure 12) and a DTD of 80% (identical manoeuvre with those in Figures 10 to 12), both in the constant-power region of the electric motor drive. Table 1 provides an objective comparison of the three gearshift strategies during each manoeuvre. Control 2 shows most of the benefit from the viewpoint of the acceleration time (a gain of more than 0.2 s when compared with control 1); however, the mean of the absolute value of jerk (the time derivative of the vehicle’s acceleration) during simulation of the upshift is higher than for control 1, with an even more significant disadvantage in terms of the peak value of jerk. Control 3 represents the best compromise between a high-performance upshift and the requirement for the expected comfort level. At a torque demand of 80%, the benefit of control 3 is much more limited than at a torque demand of 40%, because the torque increase specified by control 3 is saturated at the peak torque of the electric motor (at a motor torque demand of 100%, control 3 produces the same performance as control 2 does).

sec.title: Downshift
sec.p: Figure 14 summarises the torque and speed dynamics for a power-on downshift (kick-down) during a tip-in test (a sudden DTD request) from 25 km/h where the final DTD is 80%. The downshift takes place in the constant-torque region of the electric motor and so is performed to cause an increase in the available wheel torque. Figure 14 illustrates the oscillations (circled) in the speeds due to the effect of the tip-in manoeuvre on the torsional dynamics of the half-shafts. The transmitted torque of the second gear decreases at the start of the inertia phase owing to the change in the friction coefficient from the static value to the dynamic value. This is also evident in Figure 15 which shows that the change is partially compensated by the motion of the actuator of the friction clutch. At the end of the inertia phase, when the motor speed is at the required level and the sprag clutch is engaged, the torque of the friction clutch is progressively reduced to zero during the torque phase.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Multiple-speed transmissions for electric powertrains with a central electric motor give rise to significant performance and energy efficiency benefits in comparison with conventional single-speed transmissions. Specifically a two-speed transmission system represents the best compromise between the advantages of a multiple-speed transmission system and the simplicity of a compact and lightweight drivetrain. This article presented a novel two-speed transmission system design, together with the equations governing its dynamics. Three alternative gearshift control systems were outlined, with particular reference to the typical characteristics of electric powertrains, which require novel control algorithms for a seamless management of the upshifts within the constant-power region of the electric motor drive. A comprehensive set of simulation results demonstrated the functionality of the implemented control system and mechanical hardware, currently under experimental testing.
